messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Flea Market Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi, This is how I read it from a Chinese point of view. The third character shown on tsuba had been simplified from its traditional and formal way of writing.
messages.messageBody:
Hi,
This is how I read it from a Chinese point of view.
The third character shown on tsuba had been simplified from its traditional and formal way of writing.
That is more strokes as shown on my attached file.
Chen, Yingchaw


sosidore <sosidore@...> wrote:
Hi,
This is how I read it from a Chinese point of view.
The third character shown on tsuba had been simplified from its traditional and formal way of writing. That is more strokes as shown hereunder.
Chen, Yingchaw

Fredrik

messages.subject: Re: Flea Market Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks the clouds are very similar. I just found a reference to the wire work, its called mukade (centipede). There is a mei on this one but I don t think it
messages.messageBody:
Thanks the clouds are very similar. I just found a reference to the
wire work, its called mukade (centipede). There is a mei on this one
but I don't think it is readable.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Fredrik Persson <fredmans@b...>
wrote:

the

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Flea Market Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi, Just a suggestion!! The second tsuba with Shukado Wire is similar to Shoami Shigenobus work judging by the openwork clouds. Look at my tsuba. Could this
messages.messageBody:
Hi,
Just a suggestion!!
The second tsuba with "Shukado Wire" is similar to Shoami Shigenobus
work judging by the openwork clouds. Look at my tsuba. Could this be the
same artist or school?
http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tsuba2.htm

Also look at Richard Stein’s page he’s got a par of daisho tsuba made by
Shoami Shigenobu
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/tsuba/tsubadai.htm

But its only the clouds that are simular dont know if Shigenobu worked
with Shukado.
Regards,
Fredrik

messages.subject: Flea Market Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: I just bought these tsuba at a flea market. They were Elmer s glued to a pine board with a frame around it. Pictures are posted in folder Flea Market Tsuba
messages.messageBody:
I just bought these tsuba at a flea market. They were Elmer's glued to
a pine board with a frame around it.

Pictures are posted in folder "Flea Market Tsuba"

I'd like to get some info on them. I haven't had much luck searching
on the internet. Any suggestions or info?

Thanks in advance.
